result.markdown:
# Lab: Pandas Last session we loaded data using [Pandas](https://pandas.pydata.org/). Here we explore how to use Pandas to read in, process and explore data. As before we load pandas and use the read_csv method. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd df = pd.read_csv('data/raw/office_ratings.csv', encoding='UTF-8') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 188 entries, 0 to 187 Data columns (total 6 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 season 188 non-null int64 1 episode 188 non-null int64 2 title 188 non-null object 3 imdb_rating 188 non-null float64 4 total_votes 188 non-null int64 5 air_date 188 non-null object dtypes: float64(1), int64(3), object(2) memory usage: 8.9+ KB ``` ::: ::: ## Help! Python has inbuilt documentation. To access this add a ? before an object or method. For example, our dataframe ::: {.cell jupyter='{"outputs_hidden":true}' execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?df.info ``` ::: The dtypes property (properties of obejct are values associated with the object and are not called with a () at the end). ::: {.cell jupyter='{"outputs_hidden":true}' execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?df.dtypes ``` ::: The info method for dataframes. ::: {.cell jupyter='{"outputs_hidden":true}' execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?df.info ``` ::: The below is quite long. But goes give you the various arguments (options) you can use with the method. ::: {.cell jupyter='{"outputs_hidden":true}' execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?pd.read_csv ``` ::: The Pandas documentation is rather good. Relevent to our below work is: * [What kind of data does pandas handle?](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/getting_started/intro_tutorials/01_table_oriented.html#min-tut-01-tableoriented) * [How to calculate summary statistics?](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/getting_started/intro_tutorials/01_table_oriented.html#min-tut-01-tableoriented) * [How to create plots in pandas?](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/getting_started/intro_tutorials/04_plotting.html#min-tut-04-plotting) * [How to handle time series data with ease?](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/getting_started/intro_tutorials/09_timeseries.html#min-tut-09-timeseries) I also found [a rather nice series of lessons a kind person put together](https://bitbucket.org/hrojas/learn-pandas/src/master/). There are lots of online tutorials which will help you. ## Structure How do we find out the structure of our data? Well, the variable df is now a pandas DataFrame object. ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` pandas.core.frame.DataFrame ``` ::: ::: The DataFrame object has lots of built in methods and attributes. The info method gives us information about datatypes, dimensions and the presence of null values in our dataframe. ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 188 entries, 0 to 187 Data columns (total 6 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 season 188 non-null int64 1 episode 188 non-null int64 2 title 188 non-null object 3 imdb_rating 188 non-null float64 4 total_votes 188 non-null int64 5 air_date 188 non-null object dtypes: float64(1), int64(3), object(2) memory usage: 8.9+ KB ``` ::: ::: We can just look at the datatypes if we want. ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.dtypes ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` season int64 episode int64 title object imdb_rating float64 total_votes int64 air_date object dtype: object ``` ::: ::: Or just the dimensions. ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.shape ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ``` (188, 6) ``` ::: ::: In this case, there are only 188 rows. But for larger datasets we might want to look at the head (top 5) and tail (bottom 5) rows. ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.tail() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
183 9 19 Stairmageddon 8.0 1484 2013-04-11
184 9 20 Paper Airplane 8.0 1482 2013-04-25
185 9 21 Livin' the Dream 8.9 2041 2013-05-02
186 9 22 A.A.R.M. 9.3 2860 2013-05-09
187 9 23 Finale 9.7 7934 2013-05-16
``` ::: ::: We may need to put together a dataset. Consider the two dataframe below ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_1 = pd.read_csv('data/raw/office1.csv', encoding='UTF-8') df_2 = pd.read_csv('data/raw/office2.csv', encoding='UTF-8') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_1.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}
id season episode imdb_rating
0 5-1 5 1 8.8
1 9-13 9 13 7.7
2 5-6 5 6 8.5
3 3-23 3 23 9.3
4 9-16 9 16 8.2
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_2.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ```{=html}
id total_votes
0 4-10 2095
1 3-21 2403
2 7-24 2040
3 6-18 1769
4 8-8 1584
``` ::: ::: The total votes and imdb ratings data are split between files. There is a common column called id. We can join the two dataframes together using the common column. ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} inner_join_office_df = pd.merge(df_1, df_2, on='id', how='inner') inner_join_office_df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ```{=html}
id season episode imdb_rating total_votes
0 5-1 5 1 8.8 2501
1 9-13 9 13 7.7 1394
2 5-6 5 6 8.5 2018
3 3-23 3 23 9.3 3010
4 9-16 9 16 8.2 1572
... ... ... ... ... ...
183 5-21 5 21 8.7 2032
184 2-13 2 13 8.3 2363
185 9-6 9 6 7.8 1455
186 2-2 2 2 8.2 2736
187 3-4 3 4 8.0 2311

188 rows Ã— 5 columns

``` ::: ::: In this way you can combine datasets using common columns. We will leave that for the moment. If you want more information about merging data then see [this page](https://www.datasciencemadesimple.com/join-merge-data-frames-pandas-python/#:~:text=Merge%20%28%29%20Function%20in%20pandas%20is%20similar%20to,rows%20from%20both%20data%20frames%2C%20specify%20how%3D%20%E2%80%98outer%E2%80%99.) and the [pandas documentation](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.merge.html). ## Summary To get an overview of our data we can ask Python to 'describe our data' ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ```{=html}
season episode imdb_rating total_votes
count 188.000000 188.000000 188.000000 188.000000
mean 5.468085 11.877660 8.257447 2126.648936
std 2.386245 7.024855 0.538067 787.098275
min 1.000000 1.000000 6.700000 1393.000000
25% 3.000000 6.000000 7.900000 1631.500000
50% 6.000000 11.500000 8.200000 1952.500000
75% 7.250000 18.000000 8.600000 2379.000000
max 9.000000 26.000000 9.700000 7934.000000
``` ::: ::: or we can pull out specific statistics. ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.mean(numeric_only=True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ``` season 5.468085 episode 11.877660 imdb_rating 8.257447 total_votes 2126.648936 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Note the error triggered above due to pandas attempting to calculate the mean of the wrong type (i.e. non-numeric values). We can address that by only computing the mean of numeric values (see below): ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.mean(numeric_only=True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ``` season 5.468085 episode 11.877660 imdb_rating 8.257447 total_votes 2126.648936 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: or the sum. ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ``` season 1028 episode 2233 title PilotDiversity DayHealth CareThe AllianceBaske... imdb_rating 1552.4 total_votes 399810 air_date 2005-03-242005-03-292005-04-052005-04-122005-0... dtype: object ``` ::: ::: Similarly to what happened with `mean()`, `sum()` is adding all values in every observation of every attribute, regardless of their type. Can you see what happens with strings? And with dates? Again, we can only force to use numeric values only: ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.sum(numeric_only=True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ``` season 1028.0 episode 2233.0 imdb_rating 1552.4 total_votes 399810.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Calculating these statistics for specific columns is straight forward. ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['imdb_rating'].mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=22} ``` 8.25744680851064 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['total_votes'].sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ``` 399810 ``` ::: ::: ## Selecting subsets We can even select more than one column! ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[['imdb_rating', 'total_votes']].mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ``` imdb_rating 8.257447 total_votes 2126.648936 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Two sets of squared brackets is needed because you are passing a list of the column names to the getitem dunder method of the pandas dataframe object (thank [this stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11285613/selecting-multiple-columns-in-a-pandas-dataframe)). You can also check out the pandas documentation on [indexing and selecting data](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#basics). You can also select by row and column name using the iloc method. You can specify the [row, column]. So to choose the value in the 2nd row and 4th column. ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[2,4] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ``` 2983 ``` ::: ::: All the rows or all the columns are indicated by :. Such as, ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[:,2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=26} ``` 0 Pilot 1 Diversity Day 2 Health Care 3 The Alliance 4 Basketball ... 183 Stairmageddon 184 Paper Airplane 185 Livin' the Dream 186 A.A.R.M. 187 Finale Name: title, Length: 188, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[2,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=27} ``` season 1 episode 3 title Health Care imdb_rating 7.9 total_votes 2983 air_date 2005-04-05 Name: 2, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: We can use negative values in indexes to indicate 'from the end'. So, an index of [-10, :] returns the 10th from last row. ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[-10,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=28} ``` season 9 episode 14 title Vandalism imdb_rating 7.6 total_votes 1402 air_date 2013-01-31 Name: 178, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: Instead of using tail, we could ask for the last 10 rows with an index of [-10:, :]. I read : as 'and everything else' in these cases. ::: {.cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[-5:,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=29} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
183 9 19 Stairmageddon 8.0 1484 2013-04-11
184 9 20 Paper Airplane 8.0 1482 2013-04-25
185 9 21 Livin' the Dream 8.9 2041 2013-05-02
186 9 22 A.A.R.M. 9.3 2860 2013-05-09
187 9 23 Finale 9.7 7934 2013-05-16
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.tail() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=30} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
183 9 19 Stairmageddon 8.0 1484 2013-04-11
184 9 20 Paper Airplane 8.0 1482 2013-04-25
185 9 21 Livin' the Dream 8.9 2041 2013-05-02
186 9 22 A.A.R.M. 9.3 2860 2013-05-09
187 9 23 Finale 9.7 7934 2013-05-16
``` ::: ::: Note that the row is shown on the left. That will stop you getting lost in slices of the data. For the top ten rows ::: {.cell execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[:10,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=31} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19
5 1 6 Hot Girl 7.8 2852 2005-04-26
6 2 1 The Dundies 8.7 3213 2005-09-20
7 2 2 Sexual Harassment 8.2 2736 2005-09-27
8 2 3 Office Olympics 8.4 2742 2005-10-04
9 2 4 The Fire 8.4 2713 2005-10-11
``` ::: ::: Of course, we can run methods on these slices. We could, if we wanted to, calculate the mean imdb rating of only the first and last 100 episodes. _Note_ the indexing starts at 0 so we want the column index of 3 (0:season, 1:episode, 2:title, 3:imdb_rating). ::: {.cell execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[:100,3].mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=32} ``` 8.483 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[-100:,3].mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=33} ``` 8.062 ``` ::: ::: If you are unsure how many rows you have then the count method comes to the rescue. ::: {.cell execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[-100:,3].count() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=34} ``` 100 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=35} ```{=html}
season episode imdb_rating total_votes
count 188.000000 188.000000 188.000000 188.000000
mean 5.468085 11.877660 8.257447 2126.648936
std 2.386245 7.024855 0.538067 787.098275
min 1.000000 1.000000 6.700000 1393.000000
25% 3.000000 6.000000 7.900000 1631.500000
50% 6.000000 11.500000 8.200000 1952.500000
75% 7.250000 18.000000 8.600000 2379.000000
max 9.000000 26.000000 9.700000 7934.000000
``` ::: ::: So it looks like the last 100 episodes were less good than the first 100. I guess that is why it was cancelled. Our data is organised by season. Looking at the average by season might help. ::: {.cell execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[['season', 'imdb_rating']].groupby('season').mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=36} ```{=html}
imdb_rating
season
1 8.016667
2 8.436364
3 8.573913
4 8.600000
5 8.492308
6 8.219231
7 8.316667
8 7.666667
9 7.956522
``` ::: ::: The above line groups our dataframe by values in the season column and then displays the mean for each group. Pretty nifty. Season 8 looks pretty bad. We can look at just the rows for season 8. ::: {.cell execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[df['season'] == 8] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=37} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date
141 8 1 The List 8.2 1829 2011-09-22
142 8 2 The Incentive 8.2 1668 2011-09-29
143 8 3 Lotto 7.3 1601 2011-10-06
144 8 4 Garden Party 8.1 1717 2011-10-13
145 8 5 Spooked 7.6 1543 2011-10-27
146 8 6 Doomsday 7.8 1476 2011-11-03
147 8 7 Pam's Replacement 7.7 1563 2011-11-10
148 8 8 Gettysburg 7.0 1584 2011-11-17
149 8 9 Mrs. California 7.7 1553 2011-12-01
150 8 10 Christmas Wishes 8.0 1547 2011-12-08
151 8 11 Trivia 7.9 1488 2012-01-12
152 8 12 Pool Party 8.0 1612 2012-01-19
153 8 13 Jury Duty 7.5 1478 2012-02-02
154 8 14 Special Project 7.8 1432 2012-02-09
155 8 15 Tallahassee 7.9 1522 2012-02-16
156 8 16 After Hours 8.1 1567 2012-02-23
157 8 17 Test the Store 7.8 1478 2012-03-01
158 8 18 Last Day in Florida 7.8 1429 2012-03-08
159 8 19 Get the Girl 6.7 1642 2012-03-15
160 8 20 Welcome Party 7.2 1489 2012-04-12
161 8 21 Angry Andy 7.1 1585 2012-04-19
162 8 22 Fundraiser 7.1 1453 2012-04-26
163 8 23 Turf War 7.7 1393 2012-05-03
164 8 24 Free Family Portrait Studio 7.8 1464 2012-05-10
``` ::: ::: We can get an overview of the rating of all chapters within season 8 by: ::: {.cell execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[df['season'] == 8, 'imdb_rating'].describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=38} ``` count 24.000000 mean 7.666667 std 0.405041 min 6.700000 25% 7.450000 50% 7.800000 75% 7.925000 max 8.200000 Name: imdb_rating, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=39} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['season'] == 8 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=39} ``` 0 False 1 False 2 False 3 False 4 False ... 183 False 184 False 185 False 186 False 187 False Name: season, Length: 188, dtype: bool ``` ::: ::: Generally pretty bad, but there is clearly one very disliked episode. ## Adding columns We can add new columns pretty simply. ::: {.cell execution_count=40} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['x'] = 44 df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=40} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date x
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24 44
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29 44
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05 44
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12 44
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19 44
``` ::: ::: Our new column can be an operation on other columns ::: {.cell execution_count=41} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['rating_div_total_votes'] = df['imdb_rating'] / df['total_votes'] df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=41} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date x rating_div_total_votes
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24 44 0.002051
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29 44 0.002328
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05 44 0.002648
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12 44 0.002807
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19 44 0.002642
``` ::: ::: or as simple as adding one to every value. ::: {.cell execution_count=42} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['y'] = df['season'] + 1 df.iloc[0:5,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=42} ```{=html}
season episode title imdb_rating total_votes air_date x rating_div_total_votes y
0 1 1 Pilot 7.6 3706 2005-03-24 44 0.002051 2
1 1 2 Diversity Day 8.3 3566 2005-03-29 44 0.002328 2
2 1 3 Health Care 7.9 2983 2005-04-05 44 0.002648 2
3 1 4 The Alliance 8.1 2886 2005-04-12 44 0.002807 2
4 1 5 Basketball 8.4 3179 2005-04-19 44 0.002642 2
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=43} ``` {.python .cell-code} y = df['season'] + 1 ``` ::: ## Writing data Pandas supports writing out data frames to various formats. ::: {.cell execution_count=44} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?df.to_csv ``` ::: Now you can uncomment the code below to save your dataframe into a csv file. But before doing so, check that your `data/output` folder is empty: ::: {.cell execution_count=45} ``` {.python .cell-code} # df.to_csv('data/output/my_output_ratings.csv', encoding='UTF-8') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=46} ``` {.python .cell-code} ?df.to_excel ``` ::: Now you can uncomment the code below to save your dataframe into an excel file. But before doing so, check that your `data/output` folder is empty: ::: {.cell execution_count=47} ``` {.python .cell-code} # df.to_excel('data/output/my_output_ratings.xlsx') ``` :::
